To be so sawcie with his Masters Loue.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: It rather not becomes Endymion,
A Youth of that same molde and symetry
To be so bashfull 'fore a Gentlewoman:
As for thy Master I disclaime his loue
As one vnworthy.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: How? disclaime his loue?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And with his loue, all the whole world of men,
Except 'be thee my soule: why flyest thou mee?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Come on, Come on you little frozen-nothing,
I thinke wee must be fayne to make you take
Your loue potion in a horne, you are so skittish.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: Nay but Placenta.— Placenta holds his hands whiles Pandora kisses him.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: O most redolent!
Aurora's spiced bed is not more sweet,
Not all the odours of the early East.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: You do but mock me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: How? but mock thee sweet?
By all the Cupids in thy face, I loue thee
Beyond th' expression of a womans tongue.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: This was that simple one that could not counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: By this same nest of kisses I protest—
What would'st thou more?

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: More of your protestations.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: But canst thou loue me then?

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: Indeed faire Lady
I doe not know, I am but newly enter'd
Into this louing trade.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: You are a Wagge:
Take her by th' hand and streine it gently, so.—
Now kisse her fanne and sigh.— Good, excellent.
(Well I haue seene some Gallants in my dayes,
Though 'twas my fortune to be married,
To that same lob my husband, but no matter;)
Fy on this modesty, 'tis out of fashion,
Giue her a greene gowne quickly, shee will thanke you.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: Will not as much sattin of the same colour
To make her one doe as well?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Come, you'r a foole;
Downe with her, shee will discard you else,
As bashfull, and vnfit for Ladies seruice.— [Pandora slips downe and pulls him after her.]

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Ay me! what meane you Sir?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Why there, why so;—
Oh for Neander now and Lucius
To view this spectacle, this would crack that great
That strong and mighty bond of friendship, and
Make them both quarrell for her: nay Endymion,
As shee did pluck you downe, so 'tis your office
To take her vp, else shee'l forget her selfe
Good soule, and slumber there eternally.—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Now fie vpon you Sir, you've spoyl'd my linnen.
Pray Heauens no body saw vs: good Placenta
Reedifie what is amisse.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: All's well,
All's well, saue onely here does want a pin.
But stay I'le furnish you.—
Yes, here's a knot molested too.—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Faire Sir,
This may seeme lightnesse in mee.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Rather grauity
Who naturally tend downeward thus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: But Sir,
Let me entreat you for to entertaine
A better faith of her that is your seruant,
Giue it the right name Sir, and call it Loue.

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: I'le call it what you please faire Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Hee neuer thinks of's Master: well this Boy,
Must wee trayne farther with vs till wee meete
With our two icy Louers. Come Pandora
Will you entreate your fayrest Paramoure
T'accompany vs into the Groue? wee may
Perchance there meete his Master, whom hee seekes.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sweet shall I craue?

sp.speaker: Endy.
sp.l: Not where you may command

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: So, so, I'le now go plant this billing couple Exeunt Pan. Endym.
Vnder some pleasant tree, which done I'le goe
And range the fields for Lucius and Neander,
And bring them to behold their close embraces,
This certainely will make them hungry, and bite,
Waken their dull and sleepy appetite,
Wee neuer prize ought truly, thinke it deare,
Vntill the time of parting does draw neare.— Exit.

div.head: The Song.
div.l: To the Ladies, Ioy, delight,
And a seruant that dares fight;
No neede of painting, but a face
With perpetuity of grace.
To the Lords a gracious eye
If they haue a Mistris by.
To them both, more then all this,
Theyr Princes happinesse, and blisse.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The day's our owne, we haue the Sun, the winde,
And all that can be call'd aduantages, beare vp.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: As I'me a Gentleman, and an elder brother—

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: St, not a word.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: You wrong me Sir, I will sweare out my sweare, as
I am a Gentleman I must, and will sweare.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay sweete Master Mungrell
Mistake me not, I doe not goe about,
For to depriue you of that ornament,
That fashionable quality: I but entreat you,
For to bee frugall in your language, and,
To husband your lungs; you haue an enemy
That will require them all, had you more oathes.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: How? Doe you thinke I haue no more? by my—

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: Oh, hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: Nay, you shall heare mee, by— Ante. stops his mouth.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: O, O, O.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: By my— by— my indad law.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: By my indad law, you'le spoyle all, why you'le spend
all before the time. But see your adversaries are at hand.
This is their Captaine, their Conductor. Loue. Stay. Enter Loueall. and puls out his watch.
I'ue hit the very punto, this same minute,
Do's cut the hower into two equall portions.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You that are growne a Time-obseruer, you
With that fine pocket Saturne in your hand;
Looke this way.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: But are these your Champions?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: They are my Conqerours, if you please: but where are your imployments?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: They'le bee here immediately.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No more. Loueall, please you to take notice
Of these Gentlemen, they are of ranke, and my friends.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Sweete Sir, my only wish is that my fortunes were but of growth, to shew in what degree of honour, I hold any whom you shall vouchsafe to call a friend.— I thirst to know you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Doe not sweare yet.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.l: Why so?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay as you please.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Sir I desire you to pardon me, I must not sweare yet, my Generall will giue the word when I must vent.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: 'Tis no great matter, if you throw away Cudnigs,
Or beswiggers, or some such innocent oath vpon him.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.l: Say you so? [The Scholler offers to salute Loveall who regards him not]

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: When will he come towards me?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Sir may I know your name?

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.p: My name Sir? why Sir? I am not asham'd of my name Sir. My name is Sir M. Mung. Sir. A poore elder brother Sir. And yet not very poore neither Sir. Heire to six, or seuen hundred a yeare Sir. My father is a Gentleman Sir. I haue an Vncle that is a Iustice of Peace Sir. I can borrow his white Mare when I please sir. She stood him in thirty peeces sir.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: A Mungrell Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Only be sure you be not dash'd.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Ashamed of your name, say you? You come of a very great house, I'le assure you; I know many of the Mungrels that are able to dispend, yeerely, more then I am willing to speake of at this time; and which keepe their Sonnes as Gentlemanlike, at the Innes o'th Court with as good cloathes on their backs, as rich belts, and as faire guilt rapiers, as the best Gentlemen o'the Land Sir— O well said, come lift vp brauely now.

div.head: ACT. 3. SCE 2.
div.stage: Anter. Noddle-Empty. Loue. Will Wiseacres. Hamershin. Mr. Mungrell.

sp.speaker: Anter.
sp.p: Tis a hundred to nothing, but these are they, looke to your standing, and be sure you suffer him to offer first; you haue the more advantage.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Let me alone, if I doe not vtterly confound him, let mee neuer weare good suite of clothes more, I haue not read the Arcadia for nothing.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Anteros, a couple of friends of mine.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Sir I shall count my selfe fortunate in their acquaintance; Sweete Sir— worthy Sir.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Sans complement Mounsieur, Ie suis, vostre treshumble varlet.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: There's one of his parcels gone, he has but three more in all the world.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Signior mio molto honorifico, per testa del mio padre, io non he altro, advffirirui, che me stesso, però fate capitale di me, è splendetemi per quel chio vaglio.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Do's he speake French Sir?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: How thinke you Sir?

sp.speaker: Noddle.
sp.p: Nay but well I meane?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: O admirably, take heed what you doe, hee's a great Trauailer I tell you.

sp.speaker: Noddle.
sp.p: Gods mee! is he so? I'le not meddle with him then, I would haue tickled him else.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Signior, io mi terrei ricco s' io hanessi solamente le decime de i vostri favori.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p:
Nay Sir I am not so well skilled in the language, as I
could wish I were, for your sake, I can speake a little Sir, Un peu, Monseur, tellement quellement.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: May I be so bold as to beare your name Sir?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: My name is Nodale Empty Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: An Inns othe Court man Sir?

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: I haue pist in some greene pots in my dayes Sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Wis. My name is William Wiseacres Sir. I am of a Sanguine complexion.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: In good time Sir.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Very melancholy sometimes Sir. He offers to feele him by the nose end.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Like enough Sir

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Ha, he, he, he—

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, he,— O my sides—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Gods my life! I should loose it all were my patrimony layd on't. Come on Sir, brace me your inuention to the height, you see your Antagonist.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: To him, ferret him, ferret him.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Noble Sir may I bee so ambitious, as to desire my name, to be enrolled in the Catalogue of your well wishers.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I doe honour the very shadow of your shoe strings.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: Your mock'd Sir, hee weares bootes.

sp.speaker: Hamm.
sp.p: And am wholly your's cap a pea.

sp.speaker: Noddle.
sp.p: Pox on 't, I made full account, to haue had that next my selfe, how came hee by it trow?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What say you Sir?

sp.speaker: Noddle.
sp.p: I say Sir, that it is your best course, to take heede how you make a deed of guift of your selfe, for feare some of your friends suffer for it, for the Physnomy of your boot, tels mee, it was neuer made for you, I doe not thinke but you borrowed them.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: And I say Sir, that it is better to borrow then to take vpon trust, and neuer pay, as many such gallants as you doe.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Loueall, this heat is done, lets rub, and walke.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: Agreed, Master Empty, take some pitty on the Scholler, let him breath a little, wilt please you walke? Lovell & Nod walke. Ant. and Ham. walke.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: I am your Seruant.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well done, 'twas smartly followed; but lets walke;

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Ha, I don't thinke ne're goe Law, but I haue seene you some where.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You're beholding to your eyes for that.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Loueall, looke, looke, looke, another heate.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Don't you vse sometimes about Stamford side?

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I haue hunted, and hawked, there abouts Sir in my dayes, and beene in Sara's here too Sir, I was at the last horse race, Sir, when Veluet-heeles, and Currants run Sir, I haue some reason to remember it, I am sure, I was cheated of twenty peeces there, Ile sweare vnto you Sir as I'me a Gentleman, and an elder Brother, I'me a very foole—

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Out you Nullifidian, don't let the Gentleman sweare, tak't vpon his bare word.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Nay Sir, I'le belieue you without swearing.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Nay but conceiue me Sir. I was a very foole (as I said before) to bee drawne in after that manner, I would faine see the best cheater of them all, gull me of so much now.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Well sir, I desire your better acquaintance. I haue the best wine in Towne for you, please you to accept.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Thanke you sir. [They shake hands, he feeles him by the nose end.]

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: I think you & I are much vpon a complexion. He, he, he, you haue lost your mayden-head. If it please you Sir to come to my lodging Sir, when you come to London, I shall thinke my selfe very much bound to you, I haue some pretty bookes there to lend you, I haue Aristotle's Problemes in English, and Albertus magnus de secretis, I, as I am a liuing soule.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.p: Let's take 'em off. [They part, Lou. walkes with Wis. Ant. with Mun.]

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Troth Sir you haue a very neat suit there, I am much taken with the proportion of your hose, 'tis a deepe French Sir. I haue a Sattin suit to make shortly, and I would bestow, some twenty dozen of gold lace vpon it, if I could but purchase the knowledge of such a Taylour as your's, I should thinke my selfe beholding to my Starrs for it.

sp.speaker: Ante,
sp.p: O your walking faculty, it is the only thing, now adayes your Gentlemen practise.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, I thinke it bee time for you to seeke out for a new one, for I thinke your old one will trust you no longer.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Should you but see them walke in Paules, or in the Temple, with what a rauishing garbe— you would admire.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: He, he, you are such a merry man, but indeed I hold that Tobacco is very good for Phlegmatick complections.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Your hilt a little forwarder; very good, your very rapier speakes French; I protest hee showes in the gracefull carriage of his legge, as though he had been a man of fourtie playes, fifteene moutings.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Nay, I shall doe well in time.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Gods me! you haue staind your cloake sir, how will you doe? I doubt the Gentleman that lent you it will be angry.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Thinke you so sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well, there's no remedy, I must goe and relieue my Scholler.— Sir, a word in private, do you know that gentleman?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Yes sir, I haue read Overburies Characters; he is a silly fellow in blacke, I take it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well sir, how ever you dis-esteeme him, I could wish you would take heed of him; I wonder hee did not strike you all this while. Go to, I say no more, I hold him to be the stoutest man of his hands in all this side o'th countrey.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Is he so?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why he is sent for far and neere by the valiant of the Parishes, to play matches at football: I tell you hee is the onely Hammershin this Shire can boast of; not a Servingman can keep a legge or an arme whole for him, he ha's a pension from all the Surgeons within the compasse of fortie miles, for breaking of bones.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Nay for my part sir, let him be as tall a man as he will, I doe not care a pin for him, (doe you see) for I doe not meane to quarrell with him, onely I make account to jeere him a little.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well, take heed, say I.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Nay sir, I'le take your counsell, I'le go and fetch my rapier I left within, and then let him doe his worst. Ex. Nod.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Follow him, follow him, the exalted mushroome— a whorson butterflie, he ha's nothing to jeere you for but your borrowed cloake and bootes; and I don't thinke but they bee your owne for all his talking.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: No indeed, to tell you the truth, I borrowed them of a Batchelour of our house, mine owne lye in limbo at a Barbers shop for Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But why dost not beat him man? Gods me! beat him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Nay, I would haue bin at him, but that I was afraid—
They say many of 'em are very desperate fellowes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Faith, to doe them right, there be many of 'um that haue run through the discipline of a Bawdy-house, & learnt to quarrell there, and haue seene the entrailes of a Fence-schoole too, and in one word are sufficiently valiant; but that proues not a generalitie. There are of them (I'le warrant you) as there are of your schollers, some that weare swords, only to scare fooles.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Nay sir, I would haue you to know, that I am neither afraid of him, nor his sword: but I would not willingly die yet, if I could helpe it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fear 't not man, thou shalt liue I warrant thee, to see thy good name buried before thee. Haue you nothing about you to strike him with?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Yes, I haue the key of my study dore in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O nothing better then that, follow him, to him, to him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Shall I, i' faith? shall I?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Never stand, shall I? shall I? but doe 't.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Ne're goe, and so I will: Ile teach him to abuse any of our cloath againe. Exit Ham. He whispers him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: St, Mr Mungrell.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: As I'm a Gentleman, and an elder brother—

div.stage: He runs after them offring to draw.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: But how now Anteros? what businesse is this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Can you but hold your peace, and follow them
With your sweet William? nay, but will you goe? Ex. Loue. & William
You'l loose the banquet if not presently.

sp.speaker: Anter.
sp.l: O, O.—
Would I could loose my selfe, become a Mouse,
Or flie, that I might find a cabbin here,
To hide my selfe from these same women. O,— He climbes the tree.
But I will climbe this tree—

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I wonder much
Where our two loving friends should lye so close;
There's not a place where they doe use, but wee
Haue visited this morning. I doe long
To giue them this most pleasing spectacle:
But I will now search the Iustice his house,
Perchance they may be there.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Endymion, Exit Pla.
Another kisse; loe thus I will revenge She kisses Endym.
My selfe on those two frozen Lovers; thus,
And thus, and thus— Revenge, how sweet thou art
Vnto a woman!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O— I am afrayd
They will offend, commit, commit before mee.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And canst thou loue me, sweet Endymion?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Behold a tast what I can doe.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: These kisses He kisses her Redit in scenam Pla.
Haue not that masculine rellish yet me thinks,
Which I enjoy'd in the manly embraces
Of Lucius, or Neander.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: It is strange,
Not one about this house that can instruct mee
What should become of them, I wonder at it;
But I am glad that Constantina's flight
Is not suspected yet, so well that Boy
Doe's personate her.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Are they not there Placenta?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: St; No. O yes your Vncle is at home.
It will not yet bee dinner time this houre;
You may embrace another walke.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Content;
Endymion, wil't please you t' accompany us? Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why so then— What againe?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: You'l leaue your blubbering, Minion, come your waies.
You set your minde on such a man? yet more?
You might as well bee in loue with that same Sunne,
And should as soone enjoy it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He speakes high,
Pray heavens hee does not looke so high, for feare
He should descrie me.

sp.speaker: Vrse.
sp.l: Father, I cannot last
Out two dayes longer without Anteros.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How's that? now all my starres be mercifull!
It is a vision sure, this cannot bee.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Come, you'r a foolish girle, he marry you?
That day that hee does marry you, will I
Bring backe to life all that were dead before
The universall Deluge.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay, Ile helpe
You with a farre better expression, sir,
That day that hee does marry her, shall you
Become an honest man; a harder Province
Then to bring all the dead, to life againe.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: There are a hundred reasons (daughter) why
You should not hope it, first hee hates all women,
Next if he did not, you that are deform'd,
Lame, and mishapen, blacke, besides, ill manner'd.—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: (Hee does not see the wallet on her back.)
Haue the lest cause to hope.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: But there are (father)
Sixe hundred reasons, why I should loue him.
His manly carriage, his full breasts, his hayre,
And his fine cloathes, his golden breeches, and—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: His traiterous nose: I, I, 'tis that I know,
'Tis like the Ivy-bush vnto a Taverne,
Which tells vs there is Wine within; but I
Will take an order with you Sir e're long,
And haue you par'd.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Well I will neuer leaue
My crying (that's resolu'd) vntill I see him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O! Could I commit a crime e're I was made,
'Gainst nature worthy such a punishment?
It is decreed, I will vnman my selfe, immediately.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: What shall I doe? tis strange—
Well, 't must be so: I will goe seeke Terpander,
And mooue him to this match: most of his lands
I haue in mortgage, nay indeed they are
Forfeited to me, for the day is past
Wherein hee was bound to pay in the money,
The' advantage of this forfeiture, will I
Threaten to take, vnlesse hee does compell,
His sonne to take my daughter, to his wife.
Nay, rather then I will bee disappointed,
Hee for a portion, shall haue in his bonds,
Come daughter, bee of comfort, wee will goe
Directly to Terpander, where I'le vse
Such arguments, as shall enforce him make
His sonne both loue, and marry you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Like enough.
'Tis very likely Sir, but that this tree
Does not afford any such fruit, I'd throw He comes downe.
An old shooe after you,— such arguments
As shall enforce him make his sonne, both loue,
And marry you— well how his pills may worke
Which the old man, I know not: for my selfe
I will prouide a quicke deliuerance.
Why sheepheard? Stipes? [tic toc: ]now I must, and will
Goe forward in this plot, of my disguise.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: What make you there?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why nothing Iacke.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Come on, you are a fine fellow, to go and set them together by the eares thus, are you not?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But haue they done it finely?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Finely doe you call it? why your Scholler ha's so mauld Mr. Noddle with the key of his study dore, made such a breach in his Pericranium, that without question all his French ends haue taken their flight, through that passage; as for my cosen Mr. William, hee's crept into an old hole, behind the hangings, that in the dayes of old, h'as beene the Asylum, for decayed bootes, and shooes out of date, and there lyes hee, all alone, very melancholy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he, but how was my Gentleman, and my elder brother imploy'd all this while?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: As Gentlemen vse now adayes, in swearing; when he saw that hee could not draw his sword, hee ran vp and downe the roome, and measured out the time of the combat with oathes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Death! that I had but seene this.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Would thou had'st: for I haue e'ene taken a surfer of them. I pray thee let's inuent some way, or other
For to bee rid of them, canst thou not thinke?
Thinke, thinke, man— thinke— which I'le effect, vnlesse
All that is called Fortune, doth forsake mee.
See'st thou that brace of Cabbins, on each side
My Vncle's house?

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: They'r Dog-kennels I take it.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: They are, no more, but see they come, I'le slip
Aside lest I bee seene.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I wonder what
His brayne is now so hot in travaile with.

div.head: ACT. 3. SCE. 6.
div.stage: Ant. Love. Wise. Noddle Empty, with his head, and face all bloody.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Lend mee your hankercher, if you haue one about you Cosen, mine ha's not a dry place in it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What doe you bleede Mr. Noddle?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Yes Sir a little wild blood, hold that Cosen, vn peu Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Did not you tell mee, all his French ends were gone? vn peu will not forsake him.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Not a word.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: A whorson cowardly slaue, to strike a man e're one was aware of him, and to giue one no time, to draw his rapier—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: S'me, 'tis somewhat deepe I doubt.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Nothing by Hercules Sir, a scratch, a scratch, well I'le say nothing, but by this good blood, that runns—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Faith if you had done as that good blood does, Mr. Noddle, it had beene better for you.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: No Sir, I scorne it, I am not of that straine i'faith, and that hee shall know, the sempiternall rascall.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come on Mr. Wiseacres, I belieue you and your Kinseman are much of a complexion.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: I am very melancholy at this time.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I but you must take heed of these fits, they'l spoyle you, I heard say, that you crept into a priuate, retir'd roome e'ne now, and there convers'd with spiders and crickets, fye vpon it, you must labour against that humour; but indeed me thinks your Cosen is of a very deepe sanguine.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Ha, he, you are such a witty man.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Cosen? Yes I am much beholding to my Cosen; I might haue beene kild for him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, come, I like him well for it, the Gentleman does weigh how much the Republ. might bee impeached, by the losse of a man.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Republique? Repuddingpy. By this light, a man is little better then mad, that will keepe company with such snow-heapes, such white-liverd, counterfied lackdawes— but all's one.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I, I betwixt friends, and kinsemen; ye two are all one I know. Your Cosen is very cholerick now.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: I but I am very seldome so, for Albertus Magnus faith— [Loveall as though he came from his Vncles.]

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Now the good Gods! where shall I find these most vnfortunate Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why how now Iacke? what inauspicious wind
Ha's rays'd this cloudy weather in thy face?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: O Anteros, wee are vndone, vndone;
I'le haue this day weare black ith' Calender,
That after ages may beware of it,
It is so full of Omen—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Whats the matter? I pray thee speake. Hee faines to heare some body comming.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: O they bee here,— who's there?
Pray heauens it bee not the Constables officious industry: how will you doe Sir? You haue slaine the Scholler.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: I would I had else.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Nay Sir, this is neither time nor place for such idle wishes, here ha's beene a Surgeon already, that liues hard by, and his sentence is, that hee cannot liue aboue two howers, hee swounded six times since you left him, it seemes you bruised him so with falling on him, with the hilt of your rapier, that hee bleeds inward— I know not what to say to it— I was bewitch'd I thinke, nay thinke, thinke, thinke what course you will take, you must bee suddaine, the officers are sent for to apprehend you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is this in iest (I wonder) or in earnest?

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: Is he so indeed? I pray you tell mee true Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why, what doe you take mee to bee Sir? haue I this for my loue, and care of your safety? as you sowed, so reape for mee; I hope you will belieue your owne sences, I thinke I see the officers comming.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: 'Sme! what shall I doe? Mr. Loveall, nay good Sir, I doe belieue you, I know not which way to take.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Nay there's no stirring that way, you'l meet them in the teeth.

sp.speaker: Nodd.
sp.p: What if I goe through the backe dore, and take horse?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: They'l meet you that way too.

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: Any thing, good Sir, I beseech you, looke the dore goes, I protest twenty Serieants could not haue strucke such a feare into me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well, will you trust your fortunes into my hands?

sp.speaker: Nod.
sp.p: And liues sweet Sir.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: Quickly then enter heere, I'le shut you in untill the search bee past: nay will you in? who's there? immediately, good Master William. He shuts Nod. into one of them.

sp.speaker: Wise.
sp.p: Nay sir, I'le go to my horse if there were twenty Constables, they haue nothing to doe with mee, for I am sure I did not strike a blow, no as I'm a living soule.—

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: Gods mee, what will you doe? were not you in the company with him? that makes you accessary; haue you read so much law, and know not that? nay, will you in?— Ha, ha, he.

div.stage: He puts him into the other.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: What sai'st thou now my Anteros?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What say I?
I say thou art an arch-dissembler,
A workman in the trade: By all that's good,
I should haue been thus gull'd my selfe, thou didst
So smoothely act it, with such passion,
And anger at their incredulitie.
I was afraid thou would'st haue beat the foole,
Because he would not let himselfe be gull'd
So soone as thou wouldst haue him, but stay now—
How shall we dresse our other brace?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: That province
Is yours; as for mine owne, you see I haue
Provided for them, and conveniently:
Yet if you will embrace my counsell, write
After the copie I haue set you, doe,
Behold a patterne, and see (happily)
A chest where Stipes in the dayes of old
Ha's kept tame Conies, now uninhabited.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Right, but I feare, 'tis not capacious
Enough for both.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing, looke you here,
See you that fine spruce new erected hogstie
On the other side of Stipes house?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I doe.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: And doe you see it may be pinn'd without?
Hist, easily, softly, I'le fill up the time They enter.
With some discourse, till you haue fram'd your count'nance.

div.head: ACT. 3. SCEN. 8.
div.stage: Love. Ante Mr. Mr. Mung. Sir Hammer.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Wu'd I might ne're stirre Mr. Mungrell, if I care a pin for a hundred such, an Inns oth' Court man quoth a? nere goe, I thinke they learne nothing there, but how to swagger, and bee proud.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Nay Sir, now I must chide you, will you accuse all, for the default of some particulars? by the same reason, I'le conclude, that all yee Schollers, are coxecombes, because I see one that is so.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Meaning mee Sir?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Meaning you Sir? pardon mee 'tis meere iniustice in you, I'le assure you Sir, this whole realme, yeelds not better qualified Gentlemen, and more gentilely parted, then many of them are, and to whom, the common weale is more indebted.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Because hee has got a good suit of cloathes vpon his backe (I'le bee hang'd if they bee pay'd for yet) and a ring in 's band string, to play withall when he wants discourse, he thinkes hee may carry the ball on 's toe before him, and that no man must dare to meet him.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: No more Scholler, you haue met with him sufficiently, why Anteros, when? and here's a braue Pylades too, that would not see his Orestes opprest by multitude. [Hee claps him on the backe.]

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Arrest mee Sir? soft, and easily Sir, more words to a bargaine; s'duds! I thinke my sword be mortil'd into a snayle, [Hee flyes backe and offers to draw ]I cannot entreate him out of his shell. Arrest mee Sir? As I'm a Gentleman, and an elder brother, I owe no man a farthing that I meane to pay him. Nay come Sir, I am flesh'd now i'faith.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You will not quarrell with your friends Sir, will you?

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Friends Sir? I know not whether you be my friend, or no; I am sure you vse no friendly language.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pri'thee Scholler, tayle off Mr. Mungrell a little, hee'l never leaue now hee has drawne blood once.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Come, you'r a foole; the Gentleman's of worth, and our friend.

sp.speaker: Mung.
sp.p: Nay I haue done now, I did but try how I could quarrell a little.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Faith Sir, this would haue made a faire show in a Country Ale-house.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: Nay Sir, as soone as my father dyes, (which will not bee long I hope, for hee lyes sicke now) I'le goe to Londorn, and learne to quarrell there, for a yeare or two, and then come downe againe, and practise amongst my Tenants.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why Anteros; pray thee releiue mee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: St, not a word, for a million of worlds. Harke you Scholler. [Hee whispers with the Scholler.]

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: I hope you are not angry?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Angry old Bully? hee had a hard heart, that would be angry with thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis as I tell you, his wound ha's beene search'd by a very skilfull Surgeon, and his Pia mater is found to be perished, and when that's gone, you know there is small hope.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: None at all Sir, I've read it in Magirus, Cozen Mungrell, come hither quickly—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Now, now, how greedily the Scholler sucks it in.

sp.speaker: Mun.
sp.p: What's the matter? but is this true?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: As true as you'r a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Hee never emptyed a buttry pot after a match at footeball, with greater appetite, then hee devours this gullery.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Take heed what you doe, the least protraction is full of danger.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: O the Lord! what will become of vs?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Loveall stirre the doore a little— passion O mee! there's some body at the dore, looke, looke, creepe into this chest, I'le shut you in. He shuts vp the Scholler.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Any where good Sir.

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.p: Where will you hide me sir? I'le goe into the chest too.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Here's hardly roome enough for my selfe.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Stay, stay, stay. In good sooth Mr. Constable here's no such men this way— what say you, you three-penny cracke crowne? I tell you, they haue already taken horse. Here, here, here, creepe in, stoope man, stoope. [He shuts Mun. into the hogsty.]

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he.
Why so, wee'r now at Liberty, farewell.
My sisters wrongs, and sorrowes call for mee,
And shall be answered.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well adiew sweet Sir. Exit.
I must bee suddaine, or I'me lost for euer. [tic. toc.]
By this time sure my father melts (why sheepherd.)
The ample benefit, that shall acrew
Vnto him by this worthy match, this instant
Arriues at 's weather-beaten apprehension;
(I doe but know it, am but sure of it)
O, what a dainty pleasant thing it is
For to bee free from care! to sleepe a night,
Without the dreaming of a Creditour,
Or the disturbance of that gobling Forfeit!
It cannot but be so, vpon my soule,
Hee trades in this same cogitation,
This very minute— Stipes. che ti venga l' cancro.
Well, if hee be aboue ground, I will find him,
Or loose my selfe, I'le seeke him in the pastures. Exit.

div.head: The Song, sung by two Trebles.

sp.speaker: 1. Treb.
sp.l: But why
Doe the wing'd minutes flie
so fast away?
Stop your course yee hastie howers,
And sollicite all the powers
to let you stay.
For the earth could ne're shew forth
An object of a greater worth.

sp.speaker: 2. Treb.
sp.l: But why
Doe the wing'd minutes flie
so fast away?

sp.speaker: 1. Treb.
sp.l: It is because that they which follow,
Crowd on to haue a sight as well as they;

sp.speaker: 2. Treb.
sp.l: Harke how the ghosts of passed moments groane,
'cause they are gone:
And rayle at Fate,
And curse the date
Of their short liues expir'd so soone.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: Then stop your course, you hastie howers,
And sollicit all the powers
to let you stay,
For the earth could ne're shew forth
An object of a greater worth.

div.head: ACTVS 4. SCENA 1.
div.l: Ha, ha, he,
I haue discovered more then e're Columbus,
Or our owne water-fowle, Drake: my pretty stripling,
Which I did take away from Stipes even now,
Is prov'd a woman, prov'd an errant Lady,
That is in quest after her errant Knight,
Who is enchanted. 'Tis the Neece (forsooth)
Of our good vertuous Iustice, Mr Hooke,
Who has put on this habit for to follow
Her lover Cleopes, who has forsooke her.
All this did shee confesse to mee in private,
'Soone as she saw I had descry'd her sex
And name; but I haue stayd her pilgrimage,
Shee's fast enough, I warrant her, i'th noose
Of wedlocke now, to stirre in haste. No sooner
Did I reade woman in her lookes, but straight
I did command my mayds for to unpage her,
And cooke her in her kind, in her owne sawce;
Shee's pickeld now in some three yards of lawne:
Here shee has it, and there shee has it, fie, fie.
Was I a young man now againe, and should
Venture on such a dish to carue, by'r Lady,
I should not know which side for to begin on:
Hardly distinguish breast from backe. Well, well,—
Beshrew my heart the queanes, where e're they had them,
Haue hung good rags about her; sure they borrow'd them.
This being done, I went unto Neander,
Told him, that I had got a Boy, and drest him
Fit for his palate: he rejoyc'd, made haste
Vnto the contract, and (as kind Fortune would)
That very time a good old merry Vicar
Of my acquaintance came to visite me.
I crav'd his ayd, and (in one word) I brought her
Vayl'd, but first softned by a thousand threatnings,
If shee but mov'd towards a discovery.
The good kinde Gentleman thinking her boy,
And therefore in his power when er'e he please
For to untie the knot, is before witnesse,
Contracted to her by the Vicar.— Oh for Lucius now.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: See where hee comes; but yet how heavily!
How full of earth mee thinks his paces bee!
Hee lookes as though his teeth had playd this fortnight,
Kept Holyday. But I'le accost him.— Lucius.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The Gods befriend thee, whosoe're thou art,
That I am thought worth naming yet, not lost
Vnto all mankinde quite, though to my selfe!

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: These words doe savour of too much distraction.
You must take comfort sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Who 's that dares talke
Of comfort to me? But once name the word
That is exil'd whole Nature? good Mr Liuely
Wast you that spoke?

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: It was, and I must haue you
Remoue this same December from your lookes:
I come to make you happy.

sp.speaker: Luc,
sp.l: Thou art come
To loose thy labour then; I am below
Both all the loue, and all the spight of Fortune,
Shee will not make mee happy, and shee cannot
Make mee more wretched then I am. I lye,
Shee may doe both. But speake thou reverend head,
Has ought that 's good befallen my Neander,
That thou dar'st venture out that name of happy
So confidently upon me?— say.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: There has,
But more to you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Good, happinesse.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How? happinesse to me? thou should'st haue put
The space of fifteene ages 'twixt those words,
They are so farre from reconciliation;
Thou hast no Grammar in thee, know'st no concord.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: But I haue Musicke in me, and that's better.
I'le make thee daunce my solitary one.
Pandora shall be thine to day.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How? mine to day?

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: Thy wife, thy selfe, but in another character.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Vnspeak't againe, it must not be.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: It must.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Doest thou intend to buy me to thee? and
To breake me and my fortunes with a courtesie,
Which I shall ne're be able to repay?
Imploy thy art then, all thy quicker plots
To further my Neander in his loue:
Who by how much the more his vertues be
Greater then mine (who hardly haue so much
As will redeeme me from the name of vicious)
So much the more will apprehend the benefit,
So much the more reward thee.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Speak no further,
Pandora's thine, shee's thine, thine owne, beleeu't.
Hee is already married to another.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: I doe confesse that I am something fallen
Oft from that height of reason which before,
While I had libertie, I did enjoy:
But thou do'st wrong me much, if thou do'st thinke
That Loue has eaten up all man in mee.
I tell you, I doe know your plots, your drifts,
And all your consultations, as well
As if I had had a cabbin in your bosome,
And had from thence betrayd them; did not I
Heare when Neander did sollicite thee
For to procure a Masculine Bride for him?
Did not I heare thee promise him to doe it?
Hast thou not now perform'd it? are not they
By thy procurement now contracted? speake;
'Tis not so easie to deceiue the eyes
Of Loue, how e're our franticke Poets say
He feeds on nought but Lolium.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: Lucius,
As I doe hope to liue, as I doe prize
My lungs, my breath, laughter, and sacke, (beleeue me)
I haue Neander fast, hee 's married
To one that is as truely woman, as
Was she that did produce thee, and because
You shall be certaine of 't, 'tis Constantina.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But canst thou utter this (without a blush?)
Or hath thy many yeeres
Block'd up those channels of thy blood, that now
They are not able to afford that face,
(That starved face of thine, bankrupt of vertue)
The least reliefe? but I'le undoe your plots.
Since you doe force me, I'le confesse a secret,
Which hitherto I'ue hardly whispered
Vnto my privat'st thoughts. I am no husband,
No husband (marke you) for Pandora, nor
For any woman living; for kind Nature
Has stamped Eunuch on mee from my cradle.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: What do I heare?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That which is true.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: An Eunuch!

div.head: ACT. 4. SCEN. 3.
div.stage: Liuely, Neander, Constantina velat â facie, Lucius.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: But see Neander comes with his new Bride.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Why doe you weepe and sigh so boy? no more.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Doe you heare that?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: But see my Lucius.
I must quite alter my discourse, my garbe,
And all my actions. Hence dull melancholly,
I now must finde a face that must out-smile
A morne in Iune. Lucius, a thousand hayles.

sp.speaker: Constan.
sp.l: Vnhappy Constantina! to whom Fate
Neither permits to liue, nor yet to die.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Break off those sighs you peevish girle, or i'le— not yet?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: What meanes this strange and ponderous eye?
As though you were to take our Altitudes
Lucius? what? and doe you smile? faith speake.
How doest thou like my Choyce? perhaps you wonder
At this so sudden match; but (Friend) you see
What Love and a faire Gentlewoman can doe.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: I am the boldest wretch aliue. It cannot,
Cannot be long before he needs must know her.
What will become of thee then Liuely? ha?
You must be sure not to unvaile him Sir,
The boy would not be knowne.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: What muse you on
So deepely Lucius? does your first sonnes name
You shall beget on the most faire Pandora
Perplex you now? come on, I'le answer for you,
He shall be called Fortunate.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Not so,
Rather that name belongs to you Neander,
That shall haue no such care to trouble you:
For if my art deceiues me not (faire creature
Your hand) this wife of yours is never likely
For to beare children, but on her backe, or armes.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Why pray thee sweet?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Cause in this little vale
That lies at the foot of Venus mountaine, here,
I doe discover something too much for mother.
Come, come, Neander, these are poore devices,
Trickes of the Scene, and stale, they will not take.
And you gray haires, me thinks that thou shouldst owe
A greater and more filiall reverence
To the faire Ceremonies of the Church, then thus
To stalke with them, to make them stales unto
Such base ridiculous—

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: Lucius, doe but heare.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I will not heare thee.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: Here's a benefit
Plac'd most deservingly! I doe not like it.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: I do not apprehend him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A faire gowne
Indeed, and sope, and starch enough, to dazle
The eyes of some young countrey heire, that has
Never been drill'd through Drury lane, or Bloomsbury.
But 'pray thee (friend) whose daughter hast thou married?
What may she haue to name?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: What shall I answer?
I am i'th bryers.

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: Tell him 'tis Constantina
Our Iustices Neece.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Most excellent dissembler!
As though you know not Constantina sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But is this Constantina?

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: 'Tis truer;
Somewhat then you doe beleeue it is.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Is this
Iacke Loveall's sister?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: 'Tis.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But is this shee
Whom Cleopes once lov'd, and has forsaken?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: O me! why doe I liue and heare that name?

sp.speaker: Liue.
sp.l: Did you not mark that sigh? how smartly't came?
No, no, I haue not fitted you, I haue not.
'Tis a young Roscius I tell you. No sooner
Was Cleopes nam'd, but the arch-villaine sigh'd,
As if it had been truely Constantina.
I doe not like this businesse yet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Is this
That cryed up wonder? that Fidelia?
A sodaine change.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Yet at the last? 'tis well, I'le giue the word
Vnto Pandora: but with speciall care
That the boy knowes not of his Masters presence.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: What businesse is't that this same Midwifes face
Does fetch and carry thus about I wonder?
Hy, shee appeares againe.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: All health old man.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Old? and how old? but what's the newes that you
Are rig'd with now? and whither bound I pray you?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Next to that loving payre of friends, whose sorrowes
I haue lamented oft, and amongst which
I iudge it not the least, that while yee two
Discourse in sighes, and teares, that wanton mayde
That is the cause of all your heauinesse,
Lasciuiously does sport herselfe, and melts
In the embraces of an other.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Regardles of your woes, or her owne honour.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Now all the Gods! where is he?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Woman speake,
What is hee for a man?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: I know him not,
So farre as to his name; but this mine eyes
Dare witnesse, tis a composition
Of blood and spirits not to be despis'd.
A feature able enough to tempt; besides—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Neander, whil'st wee striue about the shaddow
Wee haue the substance ravish'd from vs.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Ha?
It cannot bee, 'tas noe affinitie
With truth; It must not bee belieu'd good Lucius.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Can yee retyre your selues vnder this tree
A little, and expect? but e're I goe,
Yee shall both promise as yee'r Gentlemen
To endure the sight with patience.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Wee will.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: It is enough.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But does this woman gull vs? Exit Plac.
Or is it reall think'st thou?

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Harke.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No more.

div.head: ACT. 4. SCE 5.
div.stage: Placenta. Lucius. Pandora. Neander, Endymion. Liuely. Constantina

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Can yee belieue it yet? are your eyes yet
Instructed?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Tis my boy Endymion,
Now hell and tortures!

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Were all odours lost,
And beggered Nature had not sweetes enough
T' embalme the dying Phoenix left, from hence
From this same lip, Shee might restore her selfe.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Ah Lucius! must he not dye?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Neander,
It is a sacriledge vnpardonable
To pluck him from that Altar.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Once more sweet—
Two pendant Cherryes when some gentle gale
Makes them to kisse, meete not with such a touch!

div.stage: [They both draw, and run at him, he saues himselfe behind Pandora.]

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Villaine, and Traytour dye.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: O me! my Master.—

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: What doe you meane? ah.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Alas.— Sweet Gentlemen.— Shee layes hold on Neanders arme.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Did all mankinde inhabit in that breast,
I'de put the Gods vnto a second trouble
For to create that species a new.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Woman forbeare.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: I doe not like these tumults.
I'le get me home and drinke a cup of Sack.

sp.speaker: Paud.
sp.l: Neander,—
Lucius,—
Ah by that Monster of my loue, your friendship,
Lucius, by these eyes of mine, which thou
A thousand times and more hast dar'd to liken
Vnto the brighter starre of Venus, which
Is both the Prologue and the Epilogue
Vnto the glorious Sun: By thine owne eyes
Which are two clearer starres, I doe coniure thee
Forbeare to prosecute such a reuenge
Vpon this innocent Boy: for here I sweare
By all those blessed powers, which know our thoughts,
I neuer lou'd him.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Most impudent woman,
Did not our eyes behold it?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O Neander,
Why doe we stand thus coldly here? and not
How out a passage through this prostitute
To trauaile to the iust destruction
Of her base Louer, and my baser vassaile?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Rather let all your fury end in me,
See here my naked brest imploy your valours:
Why doe you stand and gaze one on another?
What is the naked bosome of a Virgin
A spectacle of such terrour? if it be,
And that the fight of it hath cool'd your blouds,
Then heare me speake: you Lucius may remember
That ancient stock of loue, those many vowes,
Those many teares, those many longings, which
Haue past betwixt vs: nor can you iustly stile it
A fault of mine, that Time is now so old
And yet does see vs two; but partly yours
Partly my fathers neerenesse (for I must not
Giue it the name it merits, Couetousnesse)
Who seeing your so feruent loue vnto me,
Did striue to thrust me out with nothing, or
At least with such a portion, as you lik'd not;
Whilst thus I wauered, betwixt hope, and feare,
It fortun'd, that this Gentleman Neander
Became your Riuall: who had not long beene here,
Not long sollicited, but I (shame of women)
Began to loue yee both, and which is more
I lou'd yee with an equall flame, (but see
What Pageants Cupid can play!) it chanc'd
(Contrary to all mens expectations)
That by degrees such a strong tye of friendship
Did grow betwixt yee, that each of yee refus'd
(For his friends sake) what then was proferr'd you,
My loue; whilst I bewayl'd my miseries
Vnto this Midwife here, my friend, and grieu'd
At this my harder fortune— Good Placenta Shee weepes.
Giue them the rest.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Then take it in a word.
Supposing it the onely way to winne
One of you to her, I counsail'd her to faine
A loue vnto some other Gentleman.
Whilst we were busie in these Consultations,
As fortune would, your Page Endymion
Came hither (Lucius) to seeke his Master.
We lay the trayne for him, shee courts the Boy,
And he (poore Lad) thinking her serious
Was caught immediatly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But is this true?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Would I could call it false— But otherwise
Then was expected hath it prospered. Shee weepes.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Placenta, ah Placenta.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Who's that calls me?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Shall I disclose my selfe? I am asham'd. [They put vp their swords.]

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: If it be so, Pandora, we craue pardon.
And doe restore him life; but now (faire soule)
If thou do'st ayme to reach a life so happy
So full of all content, that thou may'st fit
Within thy Sphere (like Venus) and looke downe
On all thy Sex, and pitty them; loue this man.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Loue this man. For as for my selfe I am
Already furnish'd with a Mistris, see
My wife here— Sweetest wife.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Is this your wife?
I judge her happy who so e're shee is,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Beleeue him not, this is Boy, a villaine
(Whom I, but that—)

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Lucius forbeare.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Drest vp
In womans Cloathes by that same dotard Liuely.
Sweetest Neander leaue.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: It is a woman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: By all the gods, it is a boy, 'tis false.
But for to rob you of all hope of mee
Giue me but care, I am an Eunuch, if
You can endure to haue a frozen statue,
Sleepe by your side, whilst you awake, recount
The tedious minutes of your widdowed nights
And sigh, and thinke, and thinke, and sigh againe,
Behold an husband for you, I am he. Shee swoons.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: O me! an Eunuch?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Hold the Gentlewoman
Ay me! shee swonnes, sweetest Pandora, ah.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Ah good Lucius helpe,
Shee's gone— alas good heart. What shall I doe?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: But see shee breathes againe.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Ah hony sweet
Pandora speake.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Ah!
Hands off thou out-side of a man; and thou
Uxorious creature, I doe craue no ayde
From you, forbeare.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: How doe's my sweetest hony?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I am not well Placenta, let vs goe
Into your house a while.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Please you faire Lady
To vse my seruice?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: How? Your seruice sir?
You can doe nothing, nor doe I expect it.
But if your loue towards me be worthy, lend mee
Your Page, but for an houre.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hee is yours.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Then sir adiew.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Shall I be vanquish'd thus Plac.
In friendship? But I will once more to Liuely. Plac.
And see what further counsell hee will giue mee, Endym.
Faire wife let's goe— Rise vp you villaine boy;
Lucius farewell.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What is he gone? so soone? Exit.
To's Engineer I know, to his contriuer;
But I will follow them so fast, that not
A syllable shall passe without my Knowledge.
* * Stipes runnes against Lucius .How now you Rascall? where are your eyes I wonder?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: In as a good a headpeece as yours, I warrant you that, for all your fine cloathes, Sands, I thinke my penny as good siluer as yours, euery day i'th weeke, I'le tell you but so.

A Mayde of eighteene, to play with babes-clouts, well, 'tis no matter, Let that passe though, goe to, goe to, 'tis an ill winde that blowes no body good, cry I, sure I rose o'th right side to day, I shall haue a seruant by and by, and a lusty Knaue too, and here's the chincke, the chincke; as I was getting this rod euen now, for my wise daughter, comes me Terpanders sonne, the angry boy, the smoaker of Tobacco, the whorson which could not endure his mother, Sdnds I was afraid at first to see my selfe alone with him, he did so stare with'is rowling eyes, and 'twas no force by'r Lady, for I had fiue good shillings in my purse; But he to put me out of doubt salutes me most louingly, as thus, Stipes God saue you, Saue you Stipes— no, Stipes God saue you— Stipes be hang'd— a blockhead, Sdnds J doubt I should make but a scuruie Gentleman, I want the trick ont.— But let that passe though, I haue the mony here, and presently, my man will come, which Anteros will send me, whom, if I haue not pay'd me euery morning my forty brace of legges and caps— no more.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why so, I me fairely accoutred, as becomes a Sheepheards seruant— But swig for see my Master. Here must I quite disrobe my selfe of all my former manners, garbe, behauiour, and put the plod o'th Country on.—

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.l: How now? He whistles and dances:
What iolly whistler haue we got here trow?
Hi, hi, a dancer too? I, I, by'r Lady
For ought I know, this is the man I spoke of,
Or else if not, here's one could wish hee were.
A sturdy knaue, a lusty proper knaue.
I like him well, he ha's a backe for burthens.
You Sirrah, you;

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What say you, you?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: I say whom doe you seeke here you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I seeke a Sheepheard you.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: I am a Sheepheard.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But I seeke a Sheepheard, whose name is Stipes.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: I am the man you knaue, you come from Anteros?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yeas.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: To serue mee?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yeas.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: In good time, how now saucy Iacke? how now proud, prodigall knaue? where are your twenty legs vnto your Master? Goe to, Goe to, to worke, begin, well said. Anteros makes legs. 1.2.3.4 5 6. So, so, enough, I doe forgiue the rest. Turne you about, vm, vm, a good squat fellow, a well quarterd man, By'r Lady, and if hee had but moanes would make a pretty husband for my daughter Merda.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Has he a daughter? and are there women here? uh uh uh— O I am fallen from heauen into a Colepit!

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Why Merda, I say, my daughter Merda I say, the foolish girle's affrayd I know, go to, go to, I will forgiue her. Merda I say. But you Sir Squire 'oth' 'oth' dog, what is your name? Hy, which way looke you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My name is Ieoffry.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: I, I, how now? how Ieoffry? a hard name by'r Lady. why when?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O I could creepe into a catskin purse,
Endure the sent of a Court-fardingall
For a concealement now.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: Good-hony-sweet-sugercandy Father, forgiue mee but this time, and if euer I doe so any more, I'le neuer bee seene neither byde, or hayre againe.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Ho, ho, oho, ho a great lob, stand vp.
I doe forgiue you, but on this condition, that for your penance you shall weare this rod, stucke at your backe till night.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: With all my heart good Father sticke it on.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: So: how doest thou like my man Chuckin? goe to, looke on him well.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p:
Does hee come a wooing Father? if hee does, I'le
run away, and make him beleeue I'me coy.— [She offers to run into the house. Hee puls her backe with his hooke.]

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Whither now you great baggage? You'l come againe? But stay am not I an old foole? an old dotardly foole, that haue not enquir'd what my man can doe yet? Ieoffry.—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Is his name Ieoffry? Father, good father doe, pray you father let him dwell with vs, you know you promis'd me, that you would hire a man, and buy him a Cloake, that he might goe before mee as they doe before Gentlefolkes daughters, when my new gowne was made, I that you did, so marry did you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What haue wee now to doe?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Peace and catch a mouse.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: There's claglocks●now 'ith house to make him a cloak Sweete— hony— sugar— comfit father let him.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: No more. Ieoffry, how now you sloutch? how doe you stand? Come hither, goe to, goe to, did you euer weare a cloake in your life? answer mee roundly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No not I, I can't tell how.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Ah beggars brat! how now? but I must haue you learne, that you may man your young Mistris there sometimes. Come on let mee see how finely you can doe the feat, walke before her, follow him daughter. [Hee walkes, Merda stayes behind, tying her shoe.]

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.p: Here's a sweet office!

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: You great lobcocke you. [Hee beats him.]
Ile teach you to looke behind you, to see whether your charge followes, or no, what? would you bee gadding without your charge?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I, am I arriu'd at this?— whoffer did you strike one?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Doe you prate too? looke you here, marke but mee, I haue seene the day, when I could haue stinged it before my sweet heart.— short and thicke cittizen like, you mankin, what? two acres breadth at a stride? I, I by'r Lady; Ile cut you short in smock-timber, for this minion; is your smock so wide, with a murren to you? short and thick cittizen like: how now?

div.head: ACT. 4. SCE. 9.
div.stage: Stipes. Anteros. Merda. 2 Rusticall Seruants. two Mayds. Fidlers.

sp.speaker: 1. Rust.
sp.p: Hy, strike vp braue boyes, hy, for our towne.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p:
Hy, for your towne say you? you are a company of lazy,
lubberly knaues, there's the short and the long on't, ho, ho, boyes, ho, ho boyes? what drabs too? girles too? doxyes too? yee are a company of slowbackly Queanes, there's sauce for your eeles.

sp.speaker: 2. Rust.
sp.p: Come Kate, croude on.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O, O, the whole torrent of all woman kind is broke in vpon mee, what shall I doe?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Cuds, cuds, these are Mr. Livelyes men and mayds, that are come to dance vpon the greene. Pray you Father let mee daunce with them.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: You daunce with them? you are a great princockly puplady; there's mustard for your biefe too, since you will needs haue it; 'sonds I haue beene a wit in my dayes, there's some reliques left yet, goe to, goe to.

sp.speaker: 1. Mayd.
sp.p: Oh Stipes! I pray you let your daughter daunce with vs a little.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Daunce with you? pray you vpsolue me this question, what holy day is this? Latter Lammas? or St. Ginnyes Even?

sp.speaker: Rust. 1.
sp.p: Come on braue Sheepheard, our Master has given vs leaue to trip it for an hower, or two, I'faith we haue had a wedding at our house to day.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: A wedding? a wedding? what wedding? vpsolue mee that question.

sp.speaker: 1. Rust.
sp.p: Betweene a gentleman and a gentlewoman, but what care wee what they bee.

sp.speaker: 2. Mayd.
sp.p: Come on old Grummelseedes, what must we stand thrumming of caps all day, waiting on your graue ignorance? by the faith of my body, either let your daughter daunce with vs, or I'le make your old bones rattle in your skin, I'le lead you a Coranto I'faith.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: An Amazon, by heauens an Amazon, a Penthiseleia.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: I, I by'r Lady? are you avis'd of that?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Pray you forsooth, good-hony-sweete-plumpudding father, wee'l haue but one spirt I'faith law; Sellengers round in sippits, or put on thy smocke on munday.

sp.speaker: 1 Rust.
sp.p: But what flap-mouth'd fellow's that behind the tree there?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now comes my Cue.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Who he? another gates fellow then you take him for, goe to, goe to, it is my man I tell you.

sp.speaker: 2. Rust.
sp.p: But can bee daunce?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Oh in print, he trips it like a fayry.

sp.speaker: Ieoffry.
sp.p: Hy, hy, how now? what? tricks? how now?

sp.speaker: 2. Mayd.
sp.p: How now young man? what so modest? come on, take mee by th' hand.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Take mee Ieoffry. I'le daunce with our Ieoffry, or else I won't dance at all, no I won't, law you now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I can't dance.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p:
Hee's a lying knaue, I saw him my selfe; to him, to
to him, frolick it nimbly whilst I come back; because 'tis his first day he shall haue leaue, my daughter too, for halfe an houre, no more. Go to, go to. Exit Stipes.

div.head: ACT. 4. SCEN. 10.
div.stage: Anteros, Merda, two Rusticall Servants, 2. Ancilla, Fidlers.

sp.speaker: 2 Rust.
sp.p: But strike it out, we burne day-light.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: Ah the Lord! but where's our Ieoffrey?

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: Cuds me! I doubt the great clowne's run away.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: Whoo! hee's got up into the tree there.

sp.speaker: 1 Rust.
sp.p: Where? where? oh cuds wowkers & swowkers, I haue him by the leg: Robin, helpe here Robin.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What a murren ayles you? can't you let one alone?

sp.speaker: 2 Rust.
sp.p: Come, come, you must needs daunce, we want one.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Can't daunce.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.l: Can't you daunce, my little shamefac'd one?
Can you kisse a pretty wench in a corner?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Let one alone, I can't I tell you, I won't daunce.

sp.speaker: 1 Rust.
sp.p: I but you shall sirrah, in spite of your teeth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pish, 'won't daunce.

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: Come Merda, you must entreat him, hee'l daunce with you I know.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Prithee now Ieoffrey doe, prithee now good Ieoffrey doe, wu'd I might ne're stir law, if I don't make you a bisning posset, with a great lumpe of hony in't, when my father and mother bee gone to bed, if you will.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pish I can't daunce.

sp.speaker: 1 Rust.
sp.p: Come let the great foole alone, wee'l dance our selues.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Prithee now Ieoffrey.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What shall I say? you'l laugh at one.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Wu'd I was whipt if I doe.

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: be sworne I won't.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: Nor I on my mayden-head.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come on then, since there is no remedy. they daunce

sp.speaker: 2 Rust.
sp.p: Hi, now every one kisse his marrow.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I ne're was miserable 'till now Merda wipes her mouth, and expects

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Ieoffrey, Ieoffrey.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: Why don't you kisse your marrow?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I won't, I can't kisse.

sp.speaker: 1 Rust.
sp.p: No can't? wee'l trie that: Robin, hold his tother arme fast: so, so, now Merda, now, well sayd, againe, againe; why so then. They all laugh.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: They liue in Paradise that thrash.

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: Tihy.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: Tihy, Robin, come hither.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.l: Those happy Paracelsians are in heauen,
That trade by night i'th mineralls of the citie.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: What doe you meane to fight Merda?

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: Ay-me— I forgot the rod. They laugh.

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: Fie, why doe you blush so Merda? Shee throws it away.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: I don't blush, you are a lyer.

sp.speaker: 1 Russ.
sp.p: Fie upon you Merda, a great mayden, and blush.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: Aw, but you lye though, I did not blush, I won't daunce no more with you.

sp.speaker: 2 Rust.
sp.p: O by any meanes doe not forsake us yet, one daunce more; who was it that said shee blush'd? shee did not blush, I know she scornes to blush; come take your Ieoffrey by the hand againe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'm weary, I can't daunce no more.

sp.speaker: 1 Rust.
sp.p: Weary? faith I'de squiffe it; weary? about with it I say. They daunce againe.

div.head: ACT. 4. SCE. 11.
div.stage: Stipes, with two dead lambes vpon his hooke, & caeteri.

sp.speaker: Sti.
sp.p: O lazy varlets! is this a time to daunce? you idle persons; What will you leaue I say? looke heere I pray; doe's this same spectacle agree with turning on the toe, or capring? go to, go to, fie, fie, ah my sweet lambes, I dare bee sworne for you, yee thinke no body hurt at this instant. Come hither you my nimble skipper, upsolue me this question, what's your 'pinion must be done with these?

sp.speaker: 1 Rust.
sp.p: Pish lets away, strike vp, Stipes adiew.

sp.speaker: 1 Anc.
sp.p: Farewell Merda.

sp.speaker: 2 Anc.
sp.p: And you my ninny pease-straw-wispe that cannot kisse.

sp.speaker: 2 Rust.
sp.p: Stipes farewell, hey. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Stipes farewell? but Stipes cannot farewel, if his affaires goe thus quite arsy varsy; you whorson crab-fac'd lyzard, you left-leg'd rogue, what is there nothing else belongs unto this geare, thinke you, but onely to stare on them with your two sawcers of mustard? s'duds, either take them up quickly, and to worke about them, or Ile— Stipes strikes him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This is the second time; this once I'le suffer:
But by yon pallace of the Gods I sweare,
Let him but once more touch me with the top
Of his least finger, and I'le ramme his truncke
Into the center: I haue said it.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Are you muttering? you'l in with them, and dispatch them; goe you home too, my daughter Merda.

sp.speaker: Merd.
sp.p: Vm, vm, vm, you might haue let one daunce a little longer, so you might, so you might; I am not yet hote in my geares. Exeunt Ant. Merda.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Are you mumbling too? what my whole family turn'd rebels? s'duds— I promise you, I promise you, 'tis not my best course I see to beat my man thus often; a surly knaue by'r Lady, a surly knaue, a strong knaue too, I doe not like his lookes, he has a vineger countenance: but peace and catch a mouse, cry I.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: But see, I will enquire; honest man, a word.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: Honest man in your face, whosoe're owes you; 'sduds, haue I nothing to doe, but to prittle, prattle, with euery one I meet, thinke you? Exit.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: What an unheard of rudenesse haue we here?
Are these the manners of the countrey? well.
This is the place, as I am told, wherein
That Lucius liues, who not long since prevayl'd
With his faire flattering speeches, for to haue
My sonne Endymion to be his Page.
But oh yee awfull powers!
I had no father in mee should I suffer
Mine onely sonne to lead a servile life
With one that is mine enemy, nay more,
The ruine and subversion of my family.
O daughter Isabella!
Whilst thy false Lover melts within the armes
Of his new purchac'd Mistris, thou (poore girle)
Embracest scorne and povertie, or else
(Which I doe rather wish were true) cold death.
But I doe heare,
Since my arrivall, of some Country people,
That they haue seene, some fortnight since or more,
A pretty boy, lingring about this village
Much about her stature, and complexion,
Which did enquire for a Gentleman
That was without a Page; this may be shee,
Who for the loue of Lucius, has put on
Some strange disguise. Whom cannot loue transforme?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Ha, ha, he.
Whilst the poore flye does sport her selfe too long
About the amorous flame, she burnes her wings.
Her counterfeiting of a Loue, is now
Turn'd into earnest. Endymion's now the man
She sweares she loues; as for the other two
She has forgot their very names already.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Does not this woman name my sonne?
Let me see, is not this Endymion? it is hee, Enter Pand. Endymion.
And with him a fayre gentlewoman. Ha?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: But tell me dearest, did thy Master Lucius.
Once loue thy sister Isabella so,
Whom now he has forsaken?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Behold
That treachery repayd him.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: See, they kisse.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: But what old Gentleman is this?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'le shew my selfe.
All health to this faire loving couple.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Why do'st thou flie me?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: 'Tis my father,— father
God saue you.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Dearest sonne, my best of blessings.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: How haue you done sir, since I saw you last?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: As well as one can doe that has departed
With's onely daughter.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Why, is my sister dead?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: I know not that. But I am sure her credit,
The candor of her name is perished.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Good sir, as how? Instruct me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Ah Endymion,
Since that most treacherous Lucius left the Citie
I haue not seene her, onely I heare of her,
But little to my comfort.— But no more,
I haue forgot her, and her folly both.
Prepare thy selfe (my sonne) immediatly,
To leaue this place and service; for thy fortunes
(How e're they were before, slender and poore)
Must not now see thee hold a trencher for
A better man then Lucius. Thy old vncle
As he liv'd well, in a seasonable age
Is gone into the graue, and by his will
Hath given to thee eight thousand pound, and three
Vnto thy sister, (though unworthy) what
Else he was worth in lands and goods, is mine.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Pandora, kisse mee girle, kisse mee I say,
I haue deserued it, 'twas my invention,
My plot this (girle) th'art happy wench, th'art happy.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Is this your father sweet?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: It is faire Mistris.
Sir, I congratulate our fortunes with you;
But if you doe desire to haue my joyes
Full and o'reflow their banks, grant me your leaue
To marry this faire Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Alas,
This is not in my power Endymion:
But if thou canst procure her friends consent—

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sir feare not that, I will entreat my father.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: As for a portion, 'tis not thought upon
My son, if you be pleas'd.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Sir, I am pleas'd,
Shee is to me most deare.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Placenta, runne,
See if my father be within,— I know Ex. Pla.
(Most worthy sir) that I shall win him to it.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: But canst thou tell no newes of Isabella,
Sweet son?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: No, none at all sir.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Ah poore heart!
But 'tis no matter, I'le forget her quite. Redit in scenam Plac.
Where is thy Mr Lucius?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Your father's walk'd abroad with Mis. Vrsely
Your sister, but whither, there's none can tell me.
As yet the plot concerning Constantina to herselfe.
Is not descri'd.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Most reverend sir, wilt please you
To walke into the pastures, peradventure
There we shall meet my father.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: But I had rather
That I could compasse that same villaine Lucius,
That he might heare what he deserues. Liuely runns in, Nean. following with his sword drawne.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Villaine.

sp.speaker: Live.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Ah me! Neander with his naked sword!
Ile runne in heere.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Ah!

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Let's away good father, Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: O that thou hadst
As many liues as haires, that I might be
An age in killing thee, that I might score up
Each passing minute with a life:— But speake,
How durst thou thus abuse me?

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: I did not know
Shee was a woman.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: No, didst thou not know it?
But thou shalt know thy selfe to be a man,
One that can dye.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: — O— O—

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: How poore is this reuenge? hast thou any children,
Or kinsfolkes (speak) that I may kill them too?
Ha? wilt thou not answer? how durst thou offer this?

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Because I loued your friend Lucius
Better then you.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Better then I? that word
Does merit death though thou hadst beene preseru'd
White from thy cradle to this houre.—
Doest thou loue Lucius? ha?

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Liue; no, no thou must not;
Thou might'st haue kil'd my father, broke the vrne
Wherein my mothers ashes sleepe, farre cheaper.
But for his sake, thus much I'le grant thee, chuse
The manner of thy death— shall I take off thy head?
Or hadst thou rather dye vpon the poynt?
Thinke quickly, nay be instant.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Worthy Sir:
Let mee entreate some little space to pause
I haue not yet determin'd.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Well thou hast it. But see that it bee speedy.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Most perfidious. Contemner of all goodnesse.—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Excellent.
Nay forward, on, wee know you haue a tongue.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Ha? is this Lucius?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Where is my Isabella,
Whom thou hast loaden with disgrace? restore mee
Her honour (villaine) her good name.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: I must
Deferre my iust reuenge I see a little.
He must not know that I am angry, not
How I am gulld.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Thou base unworthy man.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Would you could raise your voyce a little sir,
You are not heard.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Thou staine of all mankind.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Thou owest thy life unto my Lucius.
I am not now at leasure for to kill thee.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Nor I for to be kild for a trick I know. Ex. Liuely.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Are you drawne drie so quickly, Mr Lickthumbe?
Haue you no more good names in pickle for me?
Nay come ifaith, let's haue an other bout.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: But is he gone? he must not so escape me. Ex. Nean.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Where is my daughter? where is my daughter, rascall?
Ah Isabella.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: So: but Sir resolue mee,
Haue yee no Empericks? no Physitians
I'th Citty, that you thus doe send your mad men
Into the country to be cur'd? but Sir
I'le leaue you.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: But I will not so leaue you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You will not?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: No, I'le be a torment to thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You will? but yet take heed that your ill language
Procures not me to turne Physician.
This sword of mine opens a veine but harshly,
Doe you heare.

lg.l: Haue you a desire to see
The glorious heavens Epitome?
Or an abstract of the Spring?
Adonis garden? or a thing
Fuller of wonder, Natures shop display'd,
Hung with the choycest pieces she has made?
Here behold it open layd.
Or else would you blesse your eyes
With a type of paradise?
Or behold how Poets faine
Ioue to sit amidst his traine?
Or see (what made Acteon rue)
Diana 'mongst her Virgin crue?
Lift up your eyes and view.

div.head: ACT. 5. SCEN. 1.
div.l: Why so then, now we are all alone. We? you great neare,
What haue you pig's in your belly? by'r Lady, If I wist
I had, I would not vnkennell this secret yet, well if there
Were hog's in my belly too, I see that it will out;
This mouth of mine was not cut out for secret's—
O wicked seruant! lewd daughter!
O Merda, Merda, thou hast lost thy selfe
div.p: For euer, thou hast defiled my house, my good name, my family. As I even now came from my sheepe, I found my daughter, at her nooning forsooth, fast a slepe vpon her bed, and there was shee (as shee vses often) campring to her selfe alone in her sleepe, 'scoursing to her selfe, but what was her 'scourse thinke you? Not about her huswifery; not how many hens were with egge, but fie vpon you Ieoffry are you not ashamed? O! Ah! fie vpon you Ieoffry are you not ashamed to touch one by the skinne? Ile tell my father (nere moue) if you will not bee quiet. I, I by'r Lady, worse then this, worse stuffe then this, what shall I say? without all doubt this left legd-rascall has dub'd mee Gran-father without Matrimony. But peace and catch a mouse cry I, some wiser then some, old birds will not be catch'd with shaffe. I haue a trick in store if it will take, to be reueng'd sufficiently— no more. Ieoffry, Why Ieoffry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What gaping knaue is that?

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p: How now Ieoffry? know you not mee Ieoffry? know you not mee? But let that passe though— I'le bee with you anon i'faith for all this geere. Come hither Left-legs, come hither. Peace and catch a mouse cry I. Did you euer when you were at your old Masters, learne to set a trap, Ieoffry?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes a mouse trap.

sp.speaker: Stip.
sp.p:
O sirrah, sirrah; but wee must haue to doe with other gates kind of cattell, I meane a fox trap Left-legs, come hither, come hither, looke you here, and learne, for this same night must
I send you into the Pastures to inuite my fine Reynold to morrow to breake-fast, goe too, goe too, hee is something too familiar with my Lambs, marke you that left-legs? A little nigher I pray you. Helpe me to twist this Corde— Well said, be a faithful seruant Ieoffry. You know I haue a daughter Ieofry. Peace and catch a Mouse Ieoffry. You great dunder nose— Souds— You'le lay both hands to work— A bots on you; you hang on my back to see you. Your tother hand in, and draw behind thus, thus looke you here.
